content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Over ten years after playing this game, I still play it to this day!! I play the single player game and desprately try to find MP games. The official server for RTCW is down now, but Enemey Territory is still going for multiplayer. Enemy territory is the MP only aspect of RTCW, and lives on. This game is so worth playing for SP alone!!!! Just buy it. It's on sale, and you'll experience one of the greatest gems of gaming ever. Sorry, but I can't say enough about the single player aspect, AND the multiplayer aspect. If you end up downloading Enemy Territory, try to find 'The Beach' map. The one where your objective is to grab documents deep below ground of an Axis base. I'm about to try to find this map myself in Enemy Territory. It is too nastalgic, Sorry for my spelling. I'm a little drunk and a little over excited from talking about this classic game. One of the BEST ever made.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I had never experienced this game before I bought it a few days ago here in Steam. I knew it was a very well received classic, and I wanted to get to know it just to educate myself since some of the people I know have expressed their love for this game.It runs very well for such an old game, and the gameplay is very accessible. The maximum resolution is a bit too small for my taste, but I believe it is easily possible to modify it otherways. I just didn't care enough to actually do it myself.The story is in the same time quite deep and still light. The overall atmosphere is supported with various notes you can find from the environment, and it helps a lot in the immersion. There is also some really fun dialogue, and the story doesn't take itself too seriously. Reminds me a lot of James Bond and Indiana Jones.The best part of it of course was to shoot a lot of nazis. Didn't care all that much about the monsters and bosses.I totally recommend this game especially if you haven't played it before like me.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												If you put a World War 2 shooter in front of me, I'd usually look up at you and say "Excuse me, this isn't what I ordered! Take it back and try again!". My dislike of them is quite high. So when everyone started singing the praises of Wolfenstein: The New Order, I thought "Looks like I better have a go with at least one of them" and gave Return to Castle Wolfenstein a shot. Turns out I quite liked it.You probably already know about Return to Castle Wolfenstein. A First-Person Shooter set in an alternate reality where the Nazis usually have access to technology they normally wouldn't do. In this case, it's occult magic! As B.J. Blazkowicz, it is your job to find out what the Nazis are up to, kill them all through fairly linear levels and not say a single word to anyone. Bullets are all the talking this fella needs.B.J. Blazkowicz will be sent to some very different locations over the course of seven chapters, slowly understanding what Heinrich Himmler and the "SS Paranormal Division" are up to. The locations are nicely constructed and have some nice variation to them.I have to say, I wasn't expecting as much stealth as there was which was a pleasent surprise. I'd definitely call this a FPS Stealth game. Unfortunately, the game does have a habit of forcing this in some parts of missions. You get seen, its "MISSION FAILED" and back to the beginning for you. That's how real life works right?These sections tend to be brief though and, outside of these constraints, the overall stealth works really well. You can be rewarded with eavesdropping over funny little conversations the Nazis have if you manage to stealth around. If you screw up majorly with stealthing, not every enemy in the map is alerted about it (unless an alarm goes off). This gaves the player the chance to recover from mistakes and keeps the game interesting.There are plenty of secrets are to be found around the levels, usually containing Nazi Gold. One thing I really liked about this game is, before you're just about to finish a level, the game will tell you how many secrets and Nazi gold you found, giving you the opportunity to turn around and go back and find it! A feature that needs to be in more games with this sort of stuff inside it. Don't let me finish the level and THEN tell me what I missed, making me reload an earlier save if I have one at all if I want to go find all the goodies.The secrets aren't too hard to find and don't add anything to the overall outcome of the game, just fun little rewards for exploration.If I have a few gripes with the game (and I always do), the  snipers can feel a bit unfair on the higher difficulty levels  and  the end boss was laughably bad. Just circle-strafe around it and shoot until dead  but they didn't sour the experience too much.Overall, an enjoyable game.For the best experience possible, use the unofficial patch from here > http://www.markshan.com/knightmare/

content:
Posted: December 20, 2011
												What a strange, strange game.  This game has an enjoyable single player game and most of the weapons are fun.  The idea is as basic as the really old old FPS games.  You start out in a room, hear strange noises, kill nazies/demons, and unlock doors.  I did love the atmosphere in this game and some of the levels looked interesting at the time... they look aged now.  My only gripe is that the few bosses the game did have....only made you wish it had more awesome bosses.This is still a decent, atmosphere, old school style game that I would recommend to anyone that missed it during its release.  I enjoyed it better than Far Cry (though the games are nothing alike), and the original Call of Duty game back in the day.   Worth it if you like old school shooter, horror, and killing nazi's~!

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Not only the best Wolfenstein game, but one of the best FPS of all time. Definition of "raising the bar". This game will always hold a special place in my heart as it was the first game I played with a 3D graphics card. Ah, the old Quantex (no longer in business) Pentium II, 233 mgz and no memory to speak of. The GeForce I crammed in was too powerful for the old bird and continually crashed the system. The game ran like♥♥♥♥♥ but it ran, and I must have played through it ten times in a row. Great action, great sound, great story. Kudos for the subtle humor and attention to detail. Nails the pseudo-serious atmosphere perfectly; you could leave all the occult stuff out and it would still be a quality war game about killing Nazis, but there's a fantastic science-fiction story to boot! Legendary.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Return to Castle Wolfenstein. General overview - average.Graphics - 5/10Sounds - 7/10Mechanics - 5/10Storyline - 4/10This game was released in 2001 and naturally, the graphics look dated. There is a total of 7 linear missions to blast your way through and, as per all ID software games, there are hidden areas and goodies to be had. The sound is average and unfortunately the developers had the German soldiers speaking in German accented English. This is very dull compared to Wolfensteins occasional screams of 'mein laben!' and 'achtung!'.Lucky there is a variety of guns to put to good use from your tradional dagger to pistols to machine guns to a tesla gun (among others). With all the options I found there was too much ammo in the game. The AI aren't completely stupid and will often hide and make you flush them out. They will also try to avoid grenades and will sometimes kick them back to you! They also have the ability to notice dead comrades and realise something is amiss and will either come searching for you or sound the alarm.The story line is a little lacking making me feel they just chucked in a heap of fluff to try and get some length to the game. It does, however, take you everywhere from towns, snow peaks, large open areas and underground caverns (to name a few) so there is plenty to see.Conclusion : Don't expect epic content from this game but if you'd like to take a crack at a classic then this would definately count.Other notes : I would go through the process of creating a saved game. I would have to double check through the save menu to make sure it had since sometimes it didn't!

												Would I recommend this game to you if you were interested in this, no. Would I recommend it if you were a huge wolfenstein fan and wanted all the games (that I know of) like I did, no.I bought The New Order and that game was amazing so I said hell I might as well try 3d, return to castle, and old blood. 3D even tho it was a damn old game it was a very fun game to play honestly and I looked forward to it. The new order and the old blood were outstandings, tho old blood was alittle too short in my opinion. But return to castle wolfenstein has honestly been one of the few games in my collection I have regret buying because honestly the game is not fun. The story is not interesting. I pretty much after mission 2 was over was forcing myself to try and finish this game and I just can't get myself to do it.The main thing that bothers me and if anyone has played Far Cry Original which I do not know if this early 2000 time period was bad with this or not but it seems like whenever I see an enemy I will go from 100 armor 100 health to little to dead instantly. Especially the damn paratrooper guys with their bigass rifles. I just try to go out of the corner and immediatly get shot without any warning and sometimes they won't even be looking at me and do damage to me. Also it wouldn't be so bad if it was not for when you load you have to wait to fade away, automatically reload to not even your most previous save, then have to select your most previous save and it not even work half the time. It gets really tedious trust me.Overall I do not recommend this game as being a huge Wolfenstein Fan but again if you are really considering this I would say try it for the first 2 hours cause thats all I needed to know.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												I remember buying this when it came out and being disappointed.  I felt I needed to see if my opinion changed after all these years... Considering there are many better games that came out before and after this, with better gameplay/mechanics/everything, this game should be skipped.Yes, it's a WW2 shooter, so it will feature all the usual weapons (and being an FPS, they are the main characters).  But they all feel boring to use (or awful like the grenades).  There are many to use, but unlike Half-Life there is limited weapon stacking (where if you press "3" you get several options).  This will make combat in the later stages of the game needlessly awkward trying to stretch and blindly press the correct key to get the venom cannon/whatever (seriously, why isn't the panzerfaust, venom, and tesla all set to one key?).  Developers: "Hey there was this amazing game called 'Half-life' and they have this great idea that unclutters the weapon selection which make combat run smoothly... let's partially implement it on the early stage weapons that become pretty superfluous as the game progresses!" The combat is garbage and requires  lots of trial and error or exploiting the A.I. of the super soldiers (which takes some trial and error to find where you can exploit it).  Imagine, you come across one of the many boring enemy designs (like a paratrooper/bullet-sponge) you land the first hits.  As you're emptying your magazine into them, they lock onto you fire back, then messing with your aim (even though you already dumped several seconds of close range shooting at them).  Why?  It makes no sense that they would implement a staggering mechanic that only affects you but not the opponents.  Developers: "So there is this game called 'Unreal' and it has great combat and balancing, so much so that winning and losing is based on player movement and skill.  Let's make movement hinder weapon accuracy (only for the player) and give all the enemys hitscan weapons!"The atmosphere and story telling is ugly and stupid.  First off, the entire premise is campy as ♥♥♥♥: nazis trying make super soldiers, zombies, nazi-ninja femme-fatales, and all that.  This would be better if the game didn't take itself so seriously.  Because it does, the developers also thought it would be cool to make everything a boring hue of poop like all the quake games. Developers: "There was this game that came out a year before that had a fun story, great level design, amazing voice acting, genuinely humorous gags, all the while being colorful and interesting to look at.  I think it was called 'No One Lives Forever.'  Let's not copy any of those things!"There are good things about this game though: the Multiplayer WAS GREAT.  But as this game is old, that community is long gone.And at least this game is short (why is the last cinematic not skippable?).Waste your money on this heap (I did twice!) if you want to not spend time playing a good game.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
Wolfenstein fans may enjoy Return to Castle Wolfenstein even without its multiplayer.Pros: Sound, ControlsCons: Graphics, Story, Gameplay, MultiplayerReturn to Castle Wolfenstein still sounds very good despite its release in 2001.  A keyboard and mouse offer excellent control although certain things, such as aiming down sights, lack polish.However, the graphics have not aged nearly as well: textures are blurry and animations, clunky.  Although some elements, such as the Nazi mysticism, add much needed interest, the story falls flat. The more interesting enemies go mostly unused: expect to grind through waves and waves of enemy soldiers.  Unfortunately, the crucial multiplayer for which the game was once highly praised has long since died away.Return to Castle Wolfenstein falls short for most players with only its mediocre single-player.6/10

number of helpful: 5 of 76 people (7%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Rating 6.5/10What is it?First Person ShooterIt is always difficult to review an older game in modern times. The question becomes does this game pass the test of time? ie. can you still have fun with this game today as you did when it first came out? And for me the answer is no. The first person shooter genre doesn't age as gracefully as other genres because the genre has been developed and refined so much over the years it becomes very easy to see all the flaws in older games.This game has some serious flaws. First off the level design is big and often times very confusing. I love exploring large levels however when the environments look the same it feels like I'm running through a maze. In addition the enemies feel like bullet sponges, at the same time enemies can fill you with an entire clip of their weapon in the span of a few seconds making saving and reloading your best weapon.  Then they added stealth in the game. Nothing says fast paced shooting like stealth. I love stealth but in doesn't work in this game. In fact the stealth mission they added to the game is possibly one of the worst implemenations of stealth I have ever seen. You have to do EXACTLY what the developers want you to do or else you will fail the mission leading to some very frustrating moments. When I played this game when it first came out I really enjoyed it, however the game has aged horribly it terms of its gameplay and design. I actually think the original DOOM games are more fun and aged better than this game. If you want some nostalgia and want to play this game then you might enjoy it, if you never played this game before your probably not going to like it at all.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												I'm not good at reviewing games, but I figured with a childhood classic like this, it would be good to tell those who are new to the old Wolfenstein games what this game has to offer. This may be long, but worth skimming if you're interested in buying.As a child, game mechanics, wonky controls, poor story and bad graphics were completely ignored and off our radars as young, fresh gamers. I remember my dad playing this game on our Windows 98 desktop. We had the Game of the Year edition which I own to this dad, but sadly got corrupted, so I bought the Steam version. My dad and I were blown away by the destructable objects, hidden areas and terrifying enemies. Now, coming back to it a decade and a half later, the novelty as not worn off. It feels the same and thinking about it critically makes me more impressed at how well this game has stood the test of time. Coming back to older games, I find myself thinking "This looks like crap" "how did I let that cinematic go and not laugh at its stupidity" "these controls are terrible". Coming back to this, I found myself amazed at the fact that I was only saying "This is still terrifying" "I don't remember that secret room" "Woah, that's awesome."This game had impressive graphics for its time and gives the same Doom/Quake FPS feel that most early FPS players are accustomed to. What makes this game unique is its level designs, enemies and believe it or not, horror-themed atmosphere build ups. Each level makes you feel like you're in that place and gives you a real sense of presence that other old FPS games completely ignore. The story is great too, though its no Metal Gear Solid or other intricate storylines, but it gives you a goal, an enemy and context. You really take on the role of an OSA agent fighting advanced Nazi technology. The action unfolds around you where in modern shooters it would be in a cutscene free from your control. The music and ambience doesn't get old and adds to the experience and sounds (although silly, like falling bones or collapsing bodies) are superb.Should you get this game? That's up to you, but not only is this game a pinnacle moment in gaming's "Golden Age", but it is still enjoyable and entertaining to this day. For those new to the Wolfenstein series who may have come in through "Wolfenstein" in 2009 or "The New Order" I highly recommend you check out this stepping stone in the series. Don't get it so you can say you've played it, get it because you will like it.10/10 My favorite game out of the thousands I've ever played.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												RtCW is a brilliantly enjoyable romp through 1943 Germany.The game generates atmosphere and suspense at an excellent - yet not too fast - rate. With creative weaponry, and carefully hidden secrets, you truly come to try to uncover everything available within a level, as you face increasingly dangerous and monstrous enemies. If I can raise one thing I didn't quite like, it would be some elements of the final Boss fight. Everything builds throughout the game to this, the culmination of Operation Resurrection - Heinrich the first. But, I felt that as he was limited in his attacks and merely a lumbering oaf, that this slightly detracted from my full enjoyment of the battle. I came equipped. I worked HARD to keep my ammunition and health high for this battle. And when he doubled over after my onslaught of lead, I expected a second form to fight, it was too easy. But he exploded and died. Disappointed, yes, but surprised? Not particularly, as this was 2001, and the concept of multiple boss forms was still a new topic, but it was an enjoyable fight while it lasted nonetheless.I reccomend you definitely spend an afternoon with a thoroughly well executed game such as this, it would be time well spent.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												RtCW is fun. It retains a lot of the corridor shooting fun of the original while still opening levels up to some degree. The graphics were good for the time and still look respectable. The facial textures still look surprisingly good. The game world did feel really empty as compared to modern shooters and even compared to the original Call of Duty that was only a couple short years after this. There's only ever infantry to fight. The level design was still good, though. It was mostly linear, but level layouts were never in a straight line. There was some light puzzle solving that kept my mind engaged. Fairly early into the game you start fighting skeletons that have come to life as the result of nazi experiments. One shoots fire and if the fire hits nazis, it turns them into undead fire monsters. It was pretty rad fighting the fire monsters. Unfortunately, that's about as interesting as the game got. From there it was mainly just fighting progressively tougher nazis, with the occassional monster boss battle. So, nazis are trying to ressurect some guy that was a bad♥♥♥♥♥1000 years ago. Considering that ressurected monster along with all the monsters it creates are taken out in short order by one singular guy, it was probably a waste of time to put so much effort into bringing him back to life. Both allied and nazi characters point this out during the game. While being a completely valid criticism for this games story, it seems like this criticism strikes at the heart of video game stories in general: they are highly unlikely and often extremely illogical. The weapons weren't all that great, except for the Sten machine gun. That was always a blast to use and  it always got my blood lust going mowing down the legions of goose-stepping goons. It can over heat so there's additional strategy to using it so as to not get caught in the middle of a fight with an unusable gun. Even after I got way more powerful weapons, I used the Sten as much as possible and it was usually just fine for handlin' business. On the technical level, loading games was kind of lame. When you die, it takes you back to the last game you loaded or the autosave at the beginning of the level. Further, you can't just pull up the load screen and load the most recent save. The game has to be quit and then the save you want to play can be loaded. There were some minor technical glitches, but nothing reloading a save couldn't fix and the game ran very smooth otherwise. It took around 8 hours to finish. RtCW was a nostalgic trip back to the dated past and it was fun.

												A seminal classic! RTCW is easily one of my all time favourite games. Bought the collector's tin edition way back when it first came out in 2001. Still have the embossed tin, and the cool little poster of the characters ... is still on the wall of the pantry after all these years. Now I have bought the Steam version, so no more disc and patching every time I want to install it.RTCW was the first shooter that really blew my mind and created an absorbing game world that was intensly atmospheric... and it really sucked me into the whole story-line. Sexy and Dangerous, athletic killer babes counterpoint beasts so ugly as to scare the pants off the best and bravest of us intrepid video gaming warriors. My favourite weapon is definately the  FG 42. A 10/10 game ...and a trip down memory lane.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Phew that was a tough game to crack toward the final stages. I played on "Don't Hurt Me" at first and quit that due to it being way too easy in the first parts, still found it easy in the first parts on "Bring Em On", but from the middle stages it got exponentially more difficult with each map! I lost patience and started using cheats for much of the final few maps I'm afraid to say! I dread to think what "I am Death Incarnate" is like. Still the difficulty settings actually DO what they SAY..... unlike so many others who only have one difficulty level, "Impossible", no matter what meaningless difficulty level you select!!!!! The FG42 armed paras were the worst, even worse than the prototype Uber Soldats! They just hit hit hit you even from 500yds and thats it, if not dead, more than 50% health gone. The number of times I had to quicksave/quickload over and over and over.....Had a few issues with a few quirks and bugs in the game too - but none were unsolvable. Annoying though! Any why did your character have so little stamina? Run for 20 seconds and he was wheezing like a 20 stoner with a cholesterol reading of 8.0!This uses the Quake 3 engine, which never was really brilliant IMO - nor was any other Quake..... nvr been a fan of the Quake games, and as for Quake 4..... that can GFI!Thankfully it's still a lot better than Quake 3..... but it still has this engine's faults, such as the tiniest pixel of scenery completely stopping you dead and grenades that refuse to bounce anywhere except back up your nose or down your crackers! Grenades were pretty much useless for anything but wall opening anyway, the enemies AI was far too good to ever get caught by a grenade! Quite impressive AI for a 2002 game it is too..... especially the expert use of cover and teamwork by the AI..... seldom seen in games of this genre. For the more "elite" troops only however, the first maps green troops had no intelligence at all! The game covered the full range of stupidity to genius very well!Other than the outstanding AI, this was a pretty formulaic FPS - but why break a winning formula? Don't expect anything new, but if you like FPS's you will like this too!

												What I love about this game is that you have to do everything yourself. There are no interactive quicktime cutscenes. Just you, a ludicrous supply of weapons and nazis. The variety of weapons and abundance of ammo lets you choose your own style. I played almost the entire game with the rifle. I'm not a big fan of hardcore stealth games and in this one, the stealh parts are pretty forgiving. There are no maps but sometimes the mission guides have useful diagrams. I didn't try the multiplayer game.Be careful with save game management as it's easy to quicksave yourself into a very bad situation.There's no controller support but I think the gameplay relies heavily on accurate aiming so I don't think it would be playable that way anyway.The only bad thing about this game is that setting the screen resolution was a bit tricky. If you get stuck just look up some help...it's an easy fix. I wish they'd do a proper update with modern resolution support and support for extra mouse buttons. Also, they could bump up the draw distance a bit more. There are some parts where you're shooting enemies of the edge of the draw limit.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												Mein leben!Return To Castle Wolfenstein is a first-person shooter reboot of the Wolfenstein series which much like its predecessor focuses on fast-paced gunplay with a number of improvements made to compensate for the new engine technologies available at the time. Firstly, unlike Wolfenstein 3D, the developers actually tried to implement a compelling story to a franchise known for not actually having a “story”. To some degree, the story in this game, at least from a concept point of view, brings something new to the table by adding elements of occult. The plot revolves around the American soldier, B.J. Blazkowicz, trying to impede the Nazis from discovering and extracting a serum hidden in an ancient tomb capable of augmenting soldiers into “Dark Knights”, an evil undead army from the 9th Century. Nazis and occult? Absurd ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but what’s not to like. However, while the concept does enhance the single-player campaign, the story itself is mostly ignorable since it generally feels like it is there to fill in the space. Blazkowicz, while a total badass, still remains one of the blandest protagonists in existence. He takes orders from his superiors like a puppet with no remorse or personal motives. Even when the Allies want to give him a medal for his efforts and persumably a well deserved break at the end, he is somewhere outside still kicking Nazi butt. Boy, he sure is souless; born with only one scope in life: to kill Nazis for eternity. Plus, it is silly how the Allies' solution to most problems is to send a "one-man army" to take down Nazi headquarters single-handedly without even breaking a sweat. But that is Wolfenstein after all; it purposely does not need to explain how Blazkowicz does it -- and hey, some ancient voodoo magic is involved, so anything is justifiable, right? Fortunately, the story did manage to create the cool villain by the name of Deathshead, who later becomes the franchise’s main antagonist.The gunplay in here is hasty but satisfying, reminiscent of older games such as Quake, Doom and Unreal Tournament, and unquestionably the strongest point of the game. While it all boils down to sprinting and shooting enemies in quick manners, the game does offer some moments of straightforward stealth where you get to sneak behind enemy lines. Additionally, there is an adequate variety in enemies from the deadly female squads in tight leather uniforms (those butts though) to juggernauts like the Über-Soldats. Different weapons are at Blazkowicz’s disposal too, with the Tesla gun being the most fun one to use, even if the MP40 probably becomes the most practical throughout most of the game, thus making pistols pretty redundant. One problem with the weapons though is the fact you never seem to run out of ammo. Retrospectively now, the gunplay does feel very basic, but mostly thanks to its fast paced action killing waves of enemies does not get dull, surprisingly enough.The level design has the mentality of most shooters back in the late '90s and early noughties based on maze-like corridors and paths, essentially allowing the player the freedom to pick whichever route to travel back and forth within the somewhat confined space. Exploration is also encouraged and rewarded by finding secret chambers filled with collectables, even if these give no gameplay advantages to the player. Graphically, at the time, the game looked great but as time went by its visuals sure look dated today. On the other hand, the same cannot be said to its soundtrack which even to this day remains memorable and rather ageless. When you can recognise a level/map by a specific track from the soundtrack, then you know the soundtrack left a good impression.Boasting a strong single-player campaign, (wherther you take the story seriously or not), many probably remember the game for its multiplayer component which at the time was very popular and considered by many superior than the campaign, even as far as being regarded one of the best multiplayer components in a game ever. I cannnot argue with that, although it was not until the highly acclaimed free standalone Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory came out that the multiplayer component peaked in popularity. Featuring a class-based gameplay similar to Team Fortress, two teams (Allies and Axis) fight each other to complete objectives on various maps. Personally, I spent far too many hours in the multiplayer alone when I was younger because it was balanced and had a very enjoyable experience. Currently, the multiplayer from Return To Castle Wolfenstein seems dead. Rest in peace.In conclusion, Return To Castle Wolfenstein still remains a classic in the eyes of many, including myself, who played it in its heydays online and/or offline, and a milestone on PC. But it definitely lost its relevance and appeal to the general public as years have passed due to more ambitious and realistic shooters showing up years later. More old-school than modern, it still is a solid shooter, nevertheless, which does not spoil the player with today’s regenerative health and cover-base mechanics and can still provide enough hours of fun mindlessly killing Nazis. Pick it up only for nostalgic purposes or if you are curious to see how fast-paced shooters were like more than a decade ago in case you never grew up with them.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
A pretty straightforward run & shoot Quake 3: Arena mod; get to an objective while killing off Nazi forces and abnormal looking enemies to keep alive. The game gradually gets tougher as you progress through the missions where new enemies who unnaturally aim better and have more powerful guns will start coming in.It could just be my computer but I get severe & random frame drops every now and again despite most of the game going at 60-90+ FPS.The maps in the game are both linear with a few very small paths to find secrets & supplies & whatnot and somewhat open where objectives may have you do some bothersome backtracking. The backtracking really can be a bother since there aren't usually any visible indications on where to go next for anything. In some relatively open maps I had to do some running around to find where I had to go which I'm usually fine with until things like locked doors that have been passed by minutes ago only become unlocked with very little to no indication of the door being unlocked after an objective is reached on another side of the map happens.Although the game is generally straightforward with its shooting there are stealth mechanics in the game, which seem pretty weak. At the very least it functions; crouch or walk up behind an enemy and use a suppressed gun or backstab with a knife to silently kill them while avoiding enemy detection. The problem is that it seems a bit out of place for a game that's generally all about being fast and shooty. The stealth is optional in most missions and I think for the most part there are times where detection is unavoidable. After an enemy spots you it seems like headshots become almost non-existant when all enemies are aware of your presence. They don't die instantly when taking in a headshot or the spreadless-shots hitting the body instead of the head despite the reticle aimed at the face. There are objectives where you can't allow the enemy to hit the alarm if you've been found which in this game is more annoying than it is fun. Fortunately objectives like those are incredibly minimal in number.There are a chunk of weapons you can have in the game almost all practical one way or another. The only guns in the game I found to be useless are the two available pistols which all shoot very slowly and are generally weakI could be observing this one wrong but the hitboxes for anything look like they go all over the place. When firing something with incredibly little spread aimed aproximately two feet away from an enemy they seem to take damage anyway.Out of the 7 missions in the game (split into 3 or 4 parts each) there are only 2 boss fights (3 if you count that upgraded version of another enemy). All of them are incredibly easy to kill and are very anti-climactic when defeated, even the final boss.It's still an overall simple and relatively short fast action Wolfenstein game (at least when you let it be that) so there's definitely fun to be had.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												Despite its age it is a good shooter with variety and many weapons. Atmospheric and absolutely ridiculous. It is not frustrating liek some old school shooters can be, but not too hard either.  Level-design is good. Areas are big and exploration is fun and rewarding.It took a little while to get into the game, the first levels where nothing special, but later on it is much more interesting. You can also play the game stealthily at times which is appreciated.Story it nothing special but it does not take itself seriously at all which is part of the charm. Warning for extremely bad clichés...Graphics can of course not compete with anything today, but it is still good considering its release, and of course should run like butter on any machine.A good prelude to the Wolfenstein a new order.

content:
Posted: March 21
 After 9 years of silence, the Wolfenstein franchise comes back strong, rebooting the series with a fresh new look & narrative, bringing you back to Castle Wolfenstein once again. Having only played RtWC for the first time recently, I have to say, it aged really well, gameplay is what you'd expect from an early 2000 first person shooter, same goes for the visuals. The story starts up the same way as the first episode of Wolf3D then continues on with its own twist, filled with medieval knights, the undeads,  squads of Nazi womans in tight leather suits ... Fun times, really.  While previous Wolfensteins were seen as run & gunning shooters, RtCW takes a different route, applying a well put stealth system offering the possibility to stealth your way throught on most parts of the game. There are some levels where stealth is obligatory that may be a bit frustrating for some though they are few and takes up to no time to go through.All & all, very enjoyable, a good 12-14 hour lenght game totally worth playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												An AMAZING classic. Great story for the time, excellent gameplay, brings back great memories of classic gameplay. Very intense gameplay at time, with very intrueging back story. Has the rare excellent balance between difficulty and gameplay pacing, something even modern games cant seem to pinch yet. The soundtrack is glorious absoletely the best there can be. On one occasion you infiltrate a V2 missle facility and experimental airfield. Only to known that they've called reinforcements when you reveal yourself and fight the Elite SS's persional division of Fallschirmjager. Armed with serious fire power (FG42s). You have 2 choices, fight them off, or try to complete the mission before they arrive. The soundtrack with amazing base booming in the background to signal their elite and deadly advance into the facility.Would YOU stay and fight the best of the best or leave the facility quickly and leave their weaponry behind?Let their theme decide:


YouTube™ Video: Return To Castle Wolfenstein Soundtrack 11. SS Elite Guard Assault - Bill Brown 

			Views: 75,786		

			Official unreleased soundtrack composed by Bill Brown for Return to Castle Wolfenstein. Track #11 Released: 2001 Genre: First-person shooter, Horror Developer: Gray Matter Interactive, id Software,...		

All my advice is, you have not played a golden game unless you have experienced...CASTLE WOLFENSTEIN.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												One of the classics for First Person Shooters and a cheap throwback to pre- modern FPS mechanics Return to Castle Wolfenstein offers the player an interesting adventure into the Nazi Occult through protagonist William "B.J." Blazkowicz. Encounter everything from your regular soldat to the depths and horrors of ancient evils, and nazi mutations! The game also offers a robust and still competitive multi-player with links to Enemy Territory; a precursor to role mechanics in online shooters. For a regular $10 or sales such as the 75% $2.49 you can't go wrong with Return to Castle Wolfenstein!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I came back to play this game again to rewrite a review. Wow is this game still something. In my opinion, this is the best Wolfenstein game to come out, and hes why I believe so.There is good weapon choices. Sten is silenced, does more damage, but to balance it, the gun can overheat after 5-6 shots. The MP-40 is a good spray gun and so is the Minigun. The game is a mixture of hard and fun. The game is really challenging, the Elite Nazi ladies are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the boss fights are tough. The game still is fun, like the Forest mission where youre forced to play stealth. That leads me to the next point. THE GAME ISN'T LINEAR. This is really rare for an FPS. RtCW features no map, compass, etc. so the game is up to you how to complete it. I found myself using the supressed luger and Sten the most to be stealthy, and the amount of secret rooms keep you interested. Also, because its not linear, there are a lot of replayablity choices. Gameplay: 10/10 - My first perfect, and it really deserves it for its choices. Either slow paced stealth where youre crouched the whole game, or fast paced shooting where your jumping around spraying, its entirely upto you.Graphics: 6/10 - Old game and the graphics aren't good. Luckly, there are HD texture packs.Overall, I normally only factor graphics as 20% of the overall grade, 40% if the gameplay is so bad and the only thing keeping it alive is the graphics. However, we could rule out the graphics for this game and I'd still rate it a solid 9/10. The gameplay is so compelling that it's a ton of fun after 2-3 playthroughs.

												Fun FPS game that plays like other first person shooters before regenerating health and scripted scenes became a staple. Aside from plain normal Nazi's, the game also pits you against female Nazi soldiers, undead zombies, undead zombies with swords, and Nazi supersoldiers that stand to stop you from completing your mission. It's a tough game but it will leave anyone satisfied if they don't mind the lack of regenerating health and along with being tired of scripted scenes that force your character to take some beating in a trap. All in all, it's worth a try for those interested in playing classic FPS games.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												I don't even know where to start. A true classic game, published by the one and only iD. Set in an alternative version of World War 2, you play Agent Blastovich (hope I got that right) as you chase down Hitler's plans in this so-called "Operation Resurrection". A ton of levels, even more secrets and brilliant gameplay, all done in the Quake 3 engine. This game was released in 2002, so get past the dated graphics and engine, and you've got yourself a game you won't soon regret buying! It's such a shame iD had to kill the master server for RtCW. If you want to play it multiplayer, go grab the free Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory. It's the multiplayer from RtCW spiced up and released as its own game

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												An AMAZING classic. Great story for the time, excellent gameplay, brings back great memories of classic gameplay. Very intense gameplay at time, with very intrueging back story. Has the rare excellent balance between difficulty and gameplay pacing, something even modern games cant seem to pinch yet. The soundtrack is glorious absoletely the best there can be. On one occasion you infiltrate a V2 missle facility and experimental airfield. Only to known that they've called reinforcements when you reveal yourself and fight the Elite SS's persional division of Fallschirmjager. Armed with serious fire power (FG42s). You have 2 choices, fight them off, or try to complete the mission before they arrive. The soundtrack with amazing base booming in the background to signal their elite and deadly advance into the facility.Would YOU stay and fight the best of the best or leave the facility quickly and leave their weaponry behind?Let their theme decide:


YouTube™ Video: Return To Castle Wolfenstein Soundtrack 11. SS Elite Guard Assault - Bill Brown 

			Views: 75,786		

			Official unreleased soundtrack composed by Bill Brown for Return to Castle Wolfenstein. Track #11 Released: 2001 Genre: First-person shooter, Horror Developer: Gray Matter Interactive, id Software,...		

All my advice is, you have not played a golden game unless you have experienced...CASTLE WOLFENSTEIN.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												6 out of 10Return to Castle Wolfenstein (RTCW) is a fast paced old school 1-st person shooter.  You get no nonsense slow motion, combos, skills etc.  Just run, point and shoot. You play as American agent something shooting Nazis and zombies. The good:1. Fast pace. 2. The main character, whatever his name is, has no existential crises.  Too many games characters have those these days. The bad: 2. The game is not memorable at all.  It has no atmosphere to speak of. 3. The missions are short and the levels forgettable.  There are secrets and loot? 4. Enemies are mostly far off.  You have to squint and shoot.  This means strafing is basically nonexistent other than in 2 boss fights. 5. Enemies' ability to spot you varies between non-existent and super hawk-eye randomly. The ugly: 6. I could not get wide screen display to work. 7. I could not switch to desktop from the game.

												After playing this in search of a meaningful FPS experience, I can say I actually found something to scratch that WW2 itch I've been dying to scratch. Just wish it had more Garand.Anyhow, this game is very well thought out,even by modern standards. It isn't so complicated that it becomes annoying, but is rather simple with it's approach to combat(which is almost silky smooth if not for the occasional sniper issues)and level design. This game has pretty much everything you'd be looking for in a Run N' Gun type game with tons of weapons and enemies, decent level design, and comfortable combat.Overall, I'd say if anyone ever gets to a point where you feel as though you're growing tired of video games, this is a gem that I believe may alleviate some of those feelings.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												I just finished this game for the first time less than 10 minutes ago... it's got to be one of my favourite shooters ever! I remember the really old Wolfenstein 3D (not the original mind, that one was way back in '84. Look it up!) on PC and Xbox 360 Arcade. For the time, it must have been mindblowing but when I played it, it was laughably bad. Yet the new Wolfensteins have felt like they've drifted too far into Call of Duty territory, as well as other common trappings of modern games with unneccessary challenges popping up all the time, 'cinematic' moments and upgrade trees. RtCW finds that sweet spot between the dated old school mid 90s shooter and the dull modern one. It's very challenging, yet adrenaline pumping and adaptive to different playstyles, like stealth. Stealth is based on alarms being sounded or not... as long as alarms aren't rung, you can go in guns blazing and win the mission. The story is just bonkers, but it's so enjoyable because of that. You've got crazy Nazi scientists summoning the dead in order to create the ultimate army of deadly super soldiers. Throw in stereotypical British and German accents and an overly sexualised group of female ninjas, and you've got a premise which would have to carry a massive badge stating boldly 'I AM TAKING THE♥♥♥♥♥♥ to get past the overly-sensitive online communities of today. I love how there is a sprint button. I could barely tell the difference between normal running and sprinting!The secrets are great. It's not based upon trial and error so much to find them, like in the 1992 3D version. The level design is impeccable. The environments and enemy design still look stylish and unique even after 15 years of graphics evolution. That there is the power of great artistic design, something lost in the processor hungry AAA shooters of today. It has its fair share of 'cheaply' difficult moments, though actually not as many as I was expecting. I could do without doors to open areas full of snipers closing without me telling them to (especially frustrating near the end). Only one boss battle out the three I actually found fun (the second one...beat him with literally 1 HP remaining!). Some of the Panzer troopers were just too difficult to take down without kiting like it was going out of fashion, and cover was often too far to get to, so a battle of attrition was often out of the question.Oh and grenades. Only ever useful against the undead. Totally useless against nearly everything else. But these are just a few nitpicks and, to be honest, can be applied to mostly any shooter of the period, even Half-Life (actually, ESPECIALLY Half-Life!). Overall, RtCW is a great blast from the past, with only a couple of the cheap difficulty tricks old PC shooters were infamous for, some of the best FPS level design ever, a crazy story and very fast paced gameplay. 9.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												In case you're itching for some old-school FPS, Return to Castle Wolfenstein does a decent job scratching that itch, but also throws in a few "newer" things into the mix. Good mission variety keeps things interesting, although game's arsenal leaves a lot to be desired.The Good:­­­RTCW mostly sticks to the classic formula of "run around, shoot baddies, look for secrets, press switches, open doors, go to next level". No silly cutscenes or quick-time events to interrupt you. It's slower-paced that its predecessor and even has a few mandatory stealth segments, but what little this detracts from the action it makes up in level variety. Stealth in this game is surprisingly competent even on levels where it's not required.The Bad:For a game that is all about shooting baddies, RtCW's 16-weapon arsenal is uninspired and poorly balanced. Many of the weapons look and feel generic, others are minor variants of said generic weapons, and the few interesting ones are too situational, gimmicky or weak to be useful. Regular and silenced submachineguns you get in the first few levels served me best for 90% of the game. I only occasionally switched to sniper rifles for long-range, or minigun and rocket-launcher against bosses. Also there's not a single shotgun in the game. Blasphemy!*note: An unofficial patch is available and is highly recommended. It adds proper widescreen support and fixes several common crashes.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Hmm that title came out as a big surprise for me. I mean, the classic Wolfenstein 3D is one of my favourite FPS games ever so I must confess that when that other title was released, I was feeling kinda shocked instead of excited to play. Well, that wasn't the only weird aspect of that story. Let me explain: Although I didn't wanted to give it a try, my mom actually wanted to! Yes, this game actually contributed a lot with her liking towards FPS games (later she even helped lil' kids on a forum, telling them how to beat some Half Life levels, but that's another story). Anyway, what else is there to say? Besides the improved graphics and now having this real 3D immersion, that newer version also started to make use of the mouse besides of the keyboard. I mean, although that combination nowadays is extremely ordinary, back then it was some kind of novelty (I gotta thank Quake for providing me a hand on getting used to that). Another aspects to be evaluated: The weapons are quite cool, as for the story, I guess it's ok, I can't really complain. Recently, some extremely generous souls developed a coop mod, which allows you to play the game with a friend. Just to finish, I know that there're more recent versions of the Wolfenstein franchise, but this one is really fun and I surely recommend it to other FPS fans (now that's what I call a plot twist).

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												I just finished this game for the first time less than 10 minutes ago... it's got to be one of my favourite shooters ever! I remember the really old Wolfenstein 3D (not the original mind, that one was way back in '84. Look it up!) on PC and Xbox 360 Arcade. For the time, it must have been mindblowing but when I played it, it was laughably bad. Yet the new Wolfensteins have felt like they've drifted too far into Call of Duty territory, as well as other common trappings of modern games with unneccessary challenges popping up all the time, 'cinematic' moments and upgrade trees. RtCW finds that sweet spot between the dated old school mid 90s shooter and the dull modern one. It's very challenging, yet adrenaline pumping and adaptive to different playstyles, like stealth. Stealth is based on alarms being sounded or not... as long as alarms aren't rung, you can go in guns blazing and win the mission. The story is just bonkers, but it's so enjoyable because of that. You've got crazy Nazi scientists summoning the dead in order to create the ultimate army of deadly super soldiers. Throw in stereotypical British and German accents and an overly sexualised group of female ninjas, and you've got a premise which would have to carry a massive badge stating boldly 'I AM TAKING THE♥♥♥♥♥♥ to get past the overly-sensitive online communities of today. I love how there is a sprint button. I could barely tell the difference between normal running and sprinting!The secrets are great. It's not based upon trial and error so much to find them, like in the 1992 3D version. The level design is impeccable. The environments and enemy design still look stylish and unique even after 15 years of graphics evolution. That there is the power of great artistic design, something lost in the processor hungry AAA shooters of today. It has its fair share of 'cheaply' difficult moments, though actually not as many as I was expecting. I could do without doors to open areas full of snipers closing without me telling them to (especially frustrating near the end). Only one boss battle out the three I actually found fun (the second one...beat him with literally 1 HP remaining!). Some of the Panzer troopers were just too difficult to take down without kiting like it was going out of fashion, and cover was often too far to get to, so a battle of attrition was often out of the question.Oh and grenades. Only ever useful against the undead. Totally useless against nearly everything else. But these are just a few nitpicks and, to be honest, can be applied to mostly any shooter of the period, even Half-Life (actually, ESPECIALLY Half-Life!). Overall, RtCW is a great blast from the past, with only a couple of the cheap difficulty tricks old PC shooters were infamous for, some of the best FPS level design ever, a crazy story and very fast paced gameplay. 9.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												RtCW is fun. It retains a lot of the corridor shooting fun of the original while still opening levels up to some degree. The graphics were good for the time and still look respectable. The facial textures still look surprisingly good. The game world did feel really empty as compared to modern shooters and even compared to the original Call of Duty that was only a couple short years after this. There's only ever infantry to fight. The level design was still good, though. It was mostly linear, but level layouts were never in a straight line. There was some light puzzle solving that kept my mind engaged. Fairly early into the game you start fighting skeletons that have come to life as the result of nazi experiments. One shoots fire and if the fire hits nazis, it turns them into undead fire monsters. It was pretty rad fighting the fire monsters. Unfortunately, that's about as interesting as the game got. From there it was mainly just fighting progressively tougher nazis, with the occassional monster boss battle. So, nazis are trying to ressurect some guy that was a bad♥♥♥♥♥1000 years ago. Considering that ressurected monster along with all the monsters it creates are taken out in short order by one singular guy, it was probably a waste of time to put so much effort into bringing him back to life. Both allied and nazi characters point this out during the game. While being a completely valid criticism for this games story, it seems like this criticism strikes at the heart of video game stories in general: they are highly unlikely and often extremely illogical. The weapons weren't all that great, except for the Sten machine gun. That was always a blast to use and  it always got my blood lust going mowing down the legions of goose-stepping goons. It can over heat so there's additional strategy to using it so as to not get caught in the middle of a fight with an unusable gun. Even after I got way more powerful weapons, I used the Sten as much as possible and it was usually just fine for handlin' business. On the technical level, loading games was kind of lame. When you die, it takes you back to the last game you loaded or the autosave at the beginning of the level. Further, you can't just pull up the load screen and load the most recent save. The game has to be quit and then the save you want to play can be loaded. There were some minor technical glitches, but nothing reloading a save couldn't fix and the game ran very smooth otherwise. It took around 8 hours to finish. RtCW was a nostalgic trip back to the dated past and it was fun.

Posted: February 24, 2016
												For a legacy game, this was much better than expected.   I previously played The New Order with better graphics, etc – however the lack of menu save & quick save required me to exit the game every hour and do a manual save.    Very frustrating when having a corrupted autosave.   Alternatively in this game, you have both menu and quick saves. Gameplay was good.   Challenges were good.   Variety was also good.Remember to R-click on your EXE, select PROPERTIES, COMPATIBILITY(tab) and set to Windows XP, SP3; then check the box "disable display scaling on high DPI settings" -- else your cursor will automatically move to the lower-right.   Do this before you launch the game the first time – else you can’t set your options and preferences with your mouse pointer going haywire.   At the time of this note, I’m on W10.

												A seminal classic! RTCW is easily one of my all time favourite games. Bought the collector's tin edition way back when it first came out in 2001. Still have the embossed tin, and the cool little poster of the characters ... is still on the wall of the pantry after all these years. I was creeped out in the catacombs, impressed by the weather effects and the sumptuous interiors in many of the buildings. Sexy and Dangerous, athletic killer babes counterpoint beasts so ugly as to scare the pants off the best and bravest of us intrepid video gaming warriors. My favourite weapon is definately the  FG 42. A 10/10 game ...and a trip down memory lane.

content:
Posted: March 21
 After 9 years of silence, the Wolfenstein franchise comes back strong, rebooting the series with a fresh new look & narrative, bringing you back to Castle Wolfenstein once again. Having only played RtWC for the first time recently, I have to say, it aged really well, gameplay is what you'd expect from an early 2000 first person shooter, same goes for the visuals. The story starts up the same way as the first episode of Wolf3D then continues on with its own twist, filled with medieval knights, the undeads,  squads of Nazi womans in tight leather suits ... Fun times, really.  While previous Wolfensteins were seen as run & gunning shooters, RtCW takes a different route, applying a well put stealth system offering the possibility to stealth your way throught on most parts of the game. There are some levels where stealth is obligatory that may be a bit frustrating for some though they are few and takes up to no time to go through.All & all, very enjoyable, a good 12-14 hour lenght game totally worth playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												This game marked the end of an era for me. Gone were the days of simplistic levels and stupid AIs. This was like nothing I had ever seen before the level of detail was amazing. The water effects and the moon lighting made me grasp for the first time the future of gaming was coming faster than I could have imagined. When I started gaming Wolfenstein 3D was the most advanced game available. Most people were playing NES for kicks and Kurt Cobain was still alive. The media had advanced so quickly gone were the days of playing Quake on dialup. This was for the first time a sleek, smart and realistic at least in appearance representation of WW2. The levels were so cozy it was a fun little trip through time with clever Germans in period clothing with even the right uniform markings for rank and branch. You respected those AIs at least you did after the first grenade to the face. It was interesting and entertaining even adding side conversations you could listen in on. The men smoked, drank and coughed sometimes laughing or listening to music just like any real person would, It was amazing. The story was good to begin with escaped spy on the run from the nazis. But then half way in you get blindsided by the cult zombie storyline it was perfect. You got a lovely dose of midevil gameplay with the creepy mummy knights and WW2 gameplay on top of it. The whole thing came together without a hitch it was one game I will always remember -SEF

												Return to castle Wolfenstein was a magnificent Revolutionizing first person shooter since the 1st game in the series and I'd say this game was at the height of it's popularity once it was released. The game features good gameplay, old fps style graphics, comfotrable controls, and tons of weapons, Nazis , Gore , and Spooky occult stuff. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												Despite having played a few hours as of now, I feel I can already review Return To Castle Wolfenstein on Steam since I played it a lot with my dad many years ago, when I was still a child (don't let mom know about it!).So I already have decent understanding of the story of this game. Heck, I know the whole story in general. The story is good: during the Second World War, you play as an American agent of some secret service who investigates certain activities of the fictional SS Paranormal Division. You operate behind enemy lines, your mate has fallen and the service refuses to send reinforcements; therefore, you stand alone. The story fits nicely in the whole Wolfenstein saga, and gives a nice thrill overall.Graphics are good for a game which is roughly 14 years old. Gameplay doesn't have any serious shortcomings either; it is just your average first person shooter. Only thing I miss is the possibility to aim down the iron sights of non-scoped weapons. The setting is an extra plus for fans of the WW2-genre, with a touch of fantasy attached to it. Bonus points for feelings of nostalgia.The only serious problem with this game is the initial inability to set the resolution higher than the default setting. Although that can be fixed by downloading and mounting a non-official patch of the game (link: http://www.markshan.com/knightmare/. Patch can be found under 'DOWNLOADS'. Extract all files in the ZIP-file in the Return To Castle Wolfenstein folder under SteamApps > commons.), it is an issue which prevents jumping right in, which some may find irritating, and should be adressed accordingly by Steam.One more important thing: make sure to save your game regularly, as the game doesn't save automatically even after completing a level. Got me back to the beginning after three levels.This game is okay and deserves to be recommended, but enthusiasts of nostalgia and the WW2-genre will find something valuable in Return To Castle Wolfenstein.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
A pretty straightforward run & shoot Quake 3: Arena mod; get to an objective while killing off Nazi forces and abnormal looking enemies to keep alive. The game gradually gets tougher as you progress through the missions where new enemies who unnaturally aim better and have more powerful guns will start coming in.It could just be my computer but I get severe & random frame drops every now and again despite most of the game going at 60-90+ FPS.The maps in the game are both linear with a few very small paths to find secrets & supplies & whatnot and somewhat open where objectives may have you do some bothersome backtracking. The backtracking really can be a bother since there aren't usually any visible indications on where to go next for anything. In some relatively open maps I had to do some running around to find where I had to go which I'm usually fine with until things like locked doors that have been passed by minutes ago only become unlocked with very little to no indication of the door being unlocked after an objective is reached on another side of the map happens.Although the game is generally straightforward with its shooting there are stealth mechanics in the game, which seem pretty weak. At the very least it functions; crouch or walk up behind an enemy and use a suppressed gun or backstab with a knife to silently kill them while avoiding enemy detection. The problem is that it seems a bit out of place for a game that's generally all about being fast and shooty. The stealth is optional in most missions and I think for the most part there are times where detection is unavoidable. After an enemy spots you it seems like headshots become almost non-existant when all enemies are aware of your presence. They don't die instantly when taking in a headshot or the spreadless-shots hitting the body instead of the head despite the reticle aimed at the face. There are objectives where you can't allow the enemy to hit the alarm if you've been found which in this game is more annoying than it is fun. Fortunately objectives like those are incredibly minimal in number.There are a chunk of weapons you can have in the game almost all practical one way or another. The only guns in the game I found to be useless are the two available pistols which all shoot very slowly and are generally weakI could be observing this one wrong but the hitboxes for anything look like they go all over the place. When firing something with incredibly little spread aimed aproximately two feet away from an enemy they seem to take damage anyway.Out of the 7 missions in the game (split into 3 or 4 parts each) there are only 2 boss fights (3 if you count that upgraded version of another enemy). All of them are incredibly easy to kill and are very anti-climactic when defeated, even the final boss.It's still an overall simple and relatively short fast action Wolfenstein game (at least when you let it be that) so there's definitely fun to be had.

content:
Posted: January 1
												Pretty solid game to blow through on a weekend or so. The shooting takes some getting used to but overall its pretty solid. The story plays second fiddle to the gunplay and such as it is given to you between missions and in cutscenes. The AI can be both brutal and hilarious at times. On the brutal side youll find yourself being spotted by enemy snipers you can barely see and they have pinpoint accuracy (I played the game with a mod so it might be different without real rtcw). On the hilarious side you can gun down a room full of guards with a silenced sten as they yell meanwhile the guy upstairs didnt hear a thing. Even on the easier difficulties youll find yourself doing more trial and error than run n gun. How you go about with the trial and error (save scumm) can affect how you feel about the game. When you are in close quarters indoor environments the game is great but when you are outdoors and have to raise no alarms in a stealth mission it will drain a bit on your drive to push forward. This is not an easy game, while the enemies dont have much health and you at full, it doesnt take much to bring you down and can be frustrating when you are being machine gunned from behind and your health goes down in a blink. Overall a pretty good game and for the price worth it imo.

												Excellent game that holds up really well after all these years.  It retains a lot of elements that made Wolfenstein 3D unique, but does so much to elevate the franchise and be a special entry on its own. content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												[Owned prior to purchase on steam.]Played this through probably two dozen times, mostly on the hardest level and yet it still does not seem to be enough to satisfy me. The game has atmosphere, realistic sounding weapons and fabulous music. Partly inspired by Alistair Maclean's 'Where Eagles Dare' (The cable car bit). The concept that the Nazi's were investigating the occult is intriguing.There are various mission of different styles. Sometimes you need to work out simple puzzles (pull levers to reveal a false wall for example) other times stealth is required and to complete the level and you must avoid being detected by the enemy. If that's not enough there is the optional (completionist) challenge of finding all hidden areas and locating all treasures in each level.Yes the graphics are dated now but it is still a very atmospheric game (especially the stark, cold snowy areas) and immensly playable. Forget this game was first released 15 years ago and allow yourself to immersed into a very believable world.

Posted: April 1, 2015
												the major complaint I have about this game is as follows:"I can't seem to quench my thirst for killing enough of those damn nazis and the undead as creatively as possible"in other words, I can't get enough of this game.reminds me a bit of the older ww2 era cod & MoH games, but much more fast paced and more gun slots that would allow you to kill those damn nazis with endless possibilities. It will be all worth it in the end once you get your hands of the venom gun (how a minigun should be like), flame thrower (does really feel like a flamethower and feels great to use one), and the tesla gun (a pure shock to use).highly recommend for the singleplayer and muliplayer on sale (its not worth it for a full price because the muliplayer doesn't work out of the box)for muliplayer though, does not work out of the box since id stopped supporting the gamebut there is a way to work around it if you are really curious to checkout the muliplayer. check out the steam discussion if you want to find out how to play muliplayer.

content:
Posted: January 23
												Sometimes the old game are the best.This game was an amazing experience, and i watched the whole things be played by someone else xD It leaves you challenged and against odds that no matter how hard you think they are, are always possible to get through, but it takes time and effort. There was a part in the game where i had to sneak into the back of a truck without alerting anyone in the area to sneak into a base, however one guard was alerted at the entrance and could not continue with the game, so be careful for this. On the mission in the woods somewhere in the beginning, make continuous saves that you may be able to go back to.Other than all that, this game was stunning and left me with awesome memories of what was and still is an amazing FPS experience.
